de.tschebbischeff.model

Class Scales

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.tschebbischeff.model.Scales

  • public class Scales
extends java.lang.Object
    Contains scales from SI units to the values you supply to the model system. It is advised to let the scales remain at the SI units, when not modeling values exceeding values in the solar system and if no precision higher than 3 digits is required.
    Since:
    2017-07-08
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Tarek

      static void setDistanceScale(double distanceScale)
      Changes the distance scale factor. 1.0 means that any distance value you supply to the model is in meters. 1000.0 means that any distance value you supply to the model is in kilometers.
      static void setMassScale(double massScale)
      Changes the mass scale factor. 1.0 means that any mass value you supply to the model is in kilograms. 1000.0 means that any mass value you supply to the model is in tons.
      static void setTimeScale(double timeScale)
      Changes the time scale factor. 1.0 means that any time value you supply to the model is in seconds. 60.0 means that any time value you supply to the model is in minutes.

      • Scales

    • Method Detail

      • setDistanceScale

        public static void setDistanceScale(double distanceScale)
        Changes the distance scale factor. 1.0 means that any distance value you supply to the model is in meters. 1000.0 means that any distance value you supply to the model is in kilometers. Generally speaking 1.0 of a distance value corresponds to distanceScale meters.
        Parameters:
        distanceScale - The new distance scale to use in the model.

      • setMassScale

        public static void setMassScale(double massScale)
        Changes the mass scale factor. 1.0 means that any mass value you supply to the model is in kilograms. 1000.0 means that any mass value you supply to the model is in tons. Generally speaking 1.0 of a mass value corresponds to massScale kilograms.
        Parameters:
        massScale - The new mass scale to use in the model.

      • setTimeScale

        public static void setTimeScale(double timeScale)
        Changes the time scale factor. 1.0 means that any time value you supply to the model is in seconds. 60.0 means that any time value you supply to the model is in minutes. Generally speaking 1.0 of a time value corresponds to timeScale seconds.
        Parameters:
        timeScale - The new time scale to use in the model.
